Title: Test Minimum Length of Username
Description: Verify that the system allows login with the minimum acceptable username length.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the login page. 2. Enter a username with the minimum length (assuming minimum length is 5 characters, e.g., "user"). 3. Enter a valid password. 4. Click the login button.
Action: Login with minimum length username
Result: The system should allow login successfully.

Title: Test Maximum Length of Username
Description: Verify that the system allows login with the maximum acceptable username length.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the login page. 2. Enter a username with the maximum length (assuming maximum length is 20 characters, e.g., "maximumlengthuser"). 3. Enter a valid password. 4. Click the login button.
Action: Login with maximum length username
Result: The system should allow login successfully.

Title: Test Username Length Just Below Minimum
Description: Verify that the system does not allow login with a username length just below the minimum.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the login page. 2. Enter a username with a length just below the minimum (e.g., "use"). 3. Enter a valid password. 4. Click the login button.
Action: Login with username length just below minimum
Result: The system should not allow login and display an error message.

Title: Test Username Length Just Above Maximum
Description: Verify that the system does not allow login with a username length just above the maximum.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the login page. 2. Enter a username with a length just above the maximum (e.g., "maximumlengthuserexceed"). 3. Enter a valid password. 4. Click the login button.
Action: Login with username length just above maximum
Result: The system should not allow login and display an error message.

Title: Test Invalid Username Format
Description: Verify that the system does not allow login with an invalid username format.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the login page. 2. Enter an invalid username format (e.g., "user@name"). 3. Enter a valid password. 4. Click the login button.
Action: Login with invalid username format
Result: The system should not allow login and display an error message.

Title: Validate User Login with Correct Credentials
Description: Verify that a user can successfully log in with valid credentials.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the login page. 2. Enter a valid username and password. 3. Click the login button.
Action: Enter valid credentials and log in.
Result: The user should be successfully logged in and redirected to the dashboard.

Title: Prevent Login with Invalid Credentials
Description: Ensure that a user cannot log in with invalid credentials.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the login page. 2. Enter an invalid username and/or password. 3. Click the login button.
Action: Enter invalid credentials and attempt to log in.
Result: The system should display an error message and prevent login.

Title: Test SQL Injection in Login Form
Description: Verify that the system is resistant to SQL injection attacks through the login form.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the login page. 2. Enter SQL injection payloads in the username and/or password fields (e.g., ' OR '1'='1). 3. Click the login button.
Action: Enter SQL injection payloads and attempt to log in.
Result: The system should display an error message and prevent login.

Title: Test Session Hijacking
Description: Ensure that session hijacking is prevented by verifying session tokens.
Precondition: A user is logged in and has an active session.
Steps: 1. Capture the session token (e.g., using browser developer tools). 2. Log out the user. 3. Use the captured session token to attempt to access the user's session.
Action: Capture and reuse session token.
Result: The system should invalidate the session token and prevent access.

Title: Test Data Exposure in URL Parameters
Description: Verify that sensitive data is not exposed through URL parameters.
Precondition: A user is logged in and has access to sensitive data.
Steps: 1. Navigate to a page that displays sensitive data. 2. Capture the URL parameters. 3. Modify the URL parameters to attempt to access unauthorized data.
Action: Modify URL parameters to attempt unauthorized access.
Result: The system should not display unauthorized data and should maintain data integrity.

Title: Load Test for Patient Registration
Description: Simulate multiple patients registering on the application simultaneously to assess the system's performance under normal conditions.
Steps: 1. Simulate 100 virtual users. 2. Each user navigates to the registration page. 3. Each user fills out and submits the registration form.
Action: Simulate multiple patient registrations concurrently.
Data: Registration form data for 100 virtual users.
Result: The system should handle all registrations within an acceptable response time (e.g., < 5 seconds per registration).

Title: Stress Test for Doctor Appointment Booking
Description: Push the system beyond its limits by simulating a high number of concurrent appointment bookings to identify breaking points and stability issues.
Precondition: Ensure there are enough available appointment slots for the test.
Steps: 1. Simulate 500 virtual users. 2. Each user searches for a doctor and selects an available time slot. 3. Each user books the appointment and receives a confirmation.
Action: Simulate a high number of concurrent appointment bookings.
Data: Doctor search and appointment booking data for 500 virtual users.
Result: The system should handle the load without crashing, but performance may degrade. Identify the breaking point.

Title: Endurance Test for Diagnostic Center Report Upload
Description: Evaluate the system's ability to sustain a prolonged load by continuously uploading reports over an extended period.
Precondition: Ensure there are pre-generated report files for the test.
Steps: 1. Simulate 50 virtual users. 2. Each user logs in and navigates to the report upload page. 3. Each user uploads a report every minute for 24 hours.
Action: Continuously upload reports over an extended period.
Result: The system should sustain the load for the entire duration without significant performance degradation.

Title: Scalability Test for Patient Login
Description: Determine the system's ability to handle increasing workloads by gradually increasing the number of concurrent logins.
Steps: 1. Start with 100 virtual users logging in concurrently. 2. Gradually increase the number of users by 100 every 5 minutes up to 1000 users. 3. Monitor the system's response time and resource utilization.
Action: Gradually increase the number of concurrent logins.
Result: The system should handle the increasing load with acceptable performance degradation.

Title: Load Test for Doctor Profile Creation
Description: Simulate multiple doctors creating profiles on the application simultaneously to assess the system's performance under normal conditions.
Steps: 1. Simulate 50 virtual users. 2. Each user navigates to the profile creation page. 3. Each user fills out and submits the profile creation form.
Action: Simulate multiple doctor profile creations concurrently.
Data: Profile creation form data for 50 virtual users.
Result: The system should handle all profile creations within an acceptable response time (e.g., < 5 seconds per creation).

Title: Patient Registration
Description: Verify that a patient can successfully register on the application.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the registration page. 2. Fill in the registration form with valid details. 3. Submit the registration form.
Action: Submit the registration form with valid details.
Data: Valid patient details (e.g., name, email, password)
Result: The patient should be successfully registered and redirected to the login page.

Title: Invalid Patient Registration
Description: Verify that the system handles invalid inputs during patient registration.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the registration page. 2. Fill in the registration form with invalid details (e.g., missing required fields). 3. Submit the registration form.
Action: Submit the registration form with invalid details.
Data: Invalid patient details (e.g., missing name, invalid email format)
Result: The system should display error messages for the invalid fields and not allow registration.

Title: Doctor Login
Description: Verify that a doctor can successfully log in to the application.
Precondition: The doctor must be registered in the system.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the login page. 2. Enter valid doctor credentials (username and password). 3. Click the login button.
Action: Log in with valid doctor credentials.
Result: The doctor should be successfully logged in and redirected to the doctor dashboard.

Title: Forgot Password
Description: Verify that a patient can reset their password using the "Forgot Password" feature.
Precondition: The patient must be registered in the system.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the login page. 2. Click on the "Forgot Password" link. 3. Enter the registered email address. 4. Click the "Reset Password" button.
Action: Reset the password using the registered email address.
Result: The system should send a password reset link to the registered email address.

Title: Book Appointment with Invalid Slot
Description: Verify that the system handles booking an appointment with an invalid time slot.
Precondition: The patient must be logged in.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the appointment booking page. 2. Select a doctor and an invalid time slot. 3. Submit the appointment booking form.
Action: Book an appointment with an invalid time slot.
Result: The system should display an error message indicating that the time slot is invalid and not allow the booking.

Title: Validate System Response Time Under Load
Description: Measure the response time of the application under varying user loads to ensure it meets performance requirements.
Precondition: The application is deployed and accessible.
Steps: 1. Simulate 100 concurrent users accessing the registration page. 2. Simulate 500 concurrent users accessing the doctor appointment booking page. 3. Simulate 1000 concurrent users accessing the patient report page. 4. Record the response time for each simulation.
Action: Simulate concurrent user access and record response times.
Result: The response time should be within acceptable limits as defined in N-EFC1.

Title: Test Access Control for Different User Roles
Description: Verify that different user roles (Patient, Doctor, Diagnostic Center) have appropriate access levels and permissions.
Precondition: The application is deployed and accessible.
Steps: 1. Log in as a Patient and attempt to access Doctor and Diagnostic Center functionalities. 2. Log in as a Doctor and attempt to access Patient and Diagnostic Center functionalities. 3. Log in as a Diagnostic Center and attempt to access Patient and Doctor functionalities. 4. Verify that each role can only access their designated functionalities.
Action: Attempt to access different functionalities with various user roles.
Data: Valid credentials for Patient, Doctor, and Diagnostic Center roles.
Result: Each user role should only be able to access their designated functionalities as per N-ACS1.

Title: Verify System Availability During Maintenance
Description: Ensure that the system remains available and functional during scheduled maintenance activities.
Precondition: The application is deployed and accessible.
Steps: 1. Schedule a maintenance activity during off-peak hours. 2. Perform the maintenance activity while monitoring system availability. 3. Verify that users can still access the application and perform necessary functions.
Action: Perform maintenance and monitor system availability.
Result: The system should remain available and functional as per N-AVL2 and N-MNT2.

Title: Test System Behavior Under Failure Conditions
Description: Assess how the system handles failures and recovers from them.
Precondition: The application is deployed and accessible.
Steps: 1. Simulate a database failure. 2. Monitor the system's behavior and response to the failure. 3. Verify that the system flags missing records and recovers within the mean time to recovery as per N-SRV1 and N-SRV2.
Action: Simulate a database failure and monitor system behavior.
Result: The system should flag missing records and recover within the defined mean time to recovery.

Title: Verify Data Integrity and Accuracy
Description: Ensure that the data processed by the system is accurate and authentic.
Precondition: The application is deployed and accessible.
Steps: 1. Upload test reports for multiple patients. 2. Verify that the reports are accurately processed and available to the respective patients. 3. Check for any discrepancies or incorrect reports that might lead to false medication as per N-INT1 and N-INT2.
Action: Upload test reports and verify accuracy.
Result: The reports should be accurately processed and available without any discrepancies.

Title: Verify Patient Data Privacy
Description: Ensure that patient data is securely stored and only accessible to authorized users.
Steps: 1. Login as a patient. 2. Navigate to the profile section. 3. Attempt to access another patient's data.
Action: Attempt to access another patient's data.
Result: The system should prevent access to another patient's data and display an error message.

Title: Validate Password Requirements
Description: Verify that the system enforces strong password policies.
Steps: 1. Navigate to the registration page. 2. Attempt to create an account with a weak password (e.g., "12345").
Action: Attempt to create an account with a weak password.
Result: The system should display an error message indicating that the password does not meet the requirements.

Title: Ensure Data Integrity During Inactivity
Description: Verify that the system logs out users after a period of inactivity and maintains data integrity.
Steps: 1. Leave the application idle for the specified inactivity timeout period. 2. Attempt to perform an action that requires authentication.
Action: Attempt to perform an action after inactivity timeout.
Result: The system should log out the user and require re-authentication.

Title: Verify Appointment Confirmation and Waiting Time Calculation
Description: Ensure that the system correctly calculates and displays the waiting time for appointments.
Steps: 1. Book an appointment with a doctor. 2. Check the appointment details for waiting time.
Action: Book an appointment and check waiting time.
Result: The system should display the correct waiting time for the appointment.

Title: Test System Availability During Maintenance
Description: Verify that the system remains available during scheduled maintenance and that users are not affected.
Steps: 1. Schedule maintenance for a specific time. 2. Attempt to access the system during the maintenance window.
Action: Attempt to access the system during maintenance.
Result: The system should remain available, and users should not be affected by the maintenance activities.
